Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Prehabilitation in Esophagogastric Cancer Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to either a prehabilitation group, receiving preoperative exercise and nutrition optimization, or a control group receiving standard care.

Participants.evidence: Conducted at McGill University Health Centre, Montreal, Canada, this randomised clinical trial included adults scheduled for elective esophagogastric cancer resection.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to either a prehabilitation group, receiving preoperative exercise and nutrition optimization, or a control group receiving standard care.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the impact of prehabilitation on functional status in these patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in functional capacity, measured by the 6-minute walk distance (6MWD), assessed preoperatively and 4 to 8 weeks postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty-eight patients were randomised, with 51 included in the primary analysis.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Sixty-eight patients were randomised, with 51 included in the primary analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The prehabilitation group demonstrated significant improvement in functional capacity compared to the control group both preoperatively (mean 6MWD change, 36.9 m vs −22.8 m; P < .001) and postoperatively (mean 6MWD change, 15.4 m vs −81.8 m; P < .001).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
